summary: So we will get a scene during the French Revolution where Aziraphale ends up in Bastille with Crowley visiting - and probably...
body:
So we will get a scene during the French Revolution where Aziraphale ends up in Bastille with Crowley visiting - and probably saving - him, we will get a scene during the Blitz with Crowley saving Aziraphale from the Nazis… it seems if this trend continues that half of the new footage will be Azi acting dumbly ending up as a damsel in distress and Crowley having to play a knight in shining armour :D.

… and I am kind of alright with that :).

summary: Who is your favorite Apocalyptic Horseperson (from the book and what we have been teased from the series) and why?
question: Who is your favorite Apocalyptic Horseperson (from the book and what we have been teased from the series) and why?
answer:
I don’t know about Favourite, but I always thought Famine was the most interesting to read about. The paradoxical nature of how they operated in the modern day was food (ha) for thought.

As for the show… I am intrigued by Pollution, but Pollution is by far the most terrifying Horseperson, imo

blog.description:
I'm a Canadian animator for children's television series. In my spare time, I'm an artist, writer, and indie game developer.
I post my art and WIP artwork of games and visual novels I'm working on. I also do commissions on deviantART, and write the occasional academic article.

summary: *Right after Crowley and Aziraphale have a minor disagreement* Aziraphale: I need to take my mind off Crowley after that row......
body:
*Right after Crowley and Aziraphale have a minor disagreement*

Aziraphale: I need to take my mind off Crowley after that row… I know, I’ll visit the library.

*Minutes later*

Librarian: Good morning. We’re doing a book showcase today.

Aziraphale: Oh? And what’s this month’s book theme?

Librarian: Snakes! :D

*Camera zooms out to show shelves upon shelves of books with snakes on the covers*

Aziraphale, looking around: Oh dear…

summary: The Tim Ferriss Show | Neil Gaiman — The Interview I've Waited 20 Years To Do
title: The Tim Ferriss Show | Neil Gaiman — The Interview I've Waited 20 Years To Do
excerpt: Neil Gaiman (@neilhimself) is the bestselling author and creator of books, graphic novels, short stories, film and television for all ages, including Neverwh...
description:
Interview with Neil. He starts talking about Good Omens and Terry at 1:07. 

I especially liked the part:

(about the show itself) It’s a lot talkier than the trailer. The trailer - a lot of it is the things going bang, because that’s what they like putting in trailers. If it were me - my trailer would have just been sort of three minutes of two characters talking.

I want to see Neil’s trailer! :)

blog.name: bettergroomedwings
blog.title: Nice & Accurate
blog.description: Good Omens Fan Blog.

summary: what's your favourite quality about Crowley?
question: what's your favourite quality about Crowley?
answer:
Ooo I love this (and nice url, btw).

I think what I most love about Crowley is his humanity. And by that, I don’t mean his compassion - I mean how utterly human he is, and tries to be. I think we’ve all gone through moments where we’ve done something to try and fit in, and Crowley is no different - his flash bastard flat is proof of that, and he turns his lights on in Tadfield to make “other humans” less nervous.

Humans are messed up and have the capabilities to be evil or divine (or both), and Crowley’s admiration of humanity seems, to my eye, to have become a sort of emulation - he wants to be a certain kind of human. And, aside from the fact his hands are tied to one side of a war he’d rather avoid, he seems to be being that human, as much as he can.

I find it just so delightful that a demon (and an angel, because Aziraphale is guilty of this as well) has such a human soul.

summary: What is Good Omens and do you recommend it?
question: What is Good Omens and do you recommend it?
answer:
ABSOLUTELY. it’s a short novel by Neil Gaiman and Terry Pratchett, and as Gaiman goes it leans Pratchett-y but if you like Discworld you will probably like this. If none of those names meant anything to you, it’s a story of a somewhat botched Apocalypse starring the child Antichrist, two mortal foes from Heaven and Hell who aren’t particularly good at being any part of that, the Four Horsepeople of the Apocalypse, and various assorted humans. It deals with themes of fate, morality, human nature, and obedience or lack thereof. Oh, and it’s a comedy, though you might cry at the end. (I did.) It’s a witty, unusual, and philosophical book and one of my all-time faves. A short read that you might want to go through again. Excellent for planes, baths, and Apocalypses.

tl;dr: I do recommend it indeed.

summary: anthony JOE crowley. anthony JAM crowley. anthony JUGLANDACEOUS crowley. anthony JABBERWOCKY crowley. anthony JAZZ crowley....
body:
anthony JOE crowley.
anthony JAM crowley.
anthony JUGLANDACEOUS crowley.
anthony JABBERWOCKY crowley.
anthony JAZZ crowley.
anthony JEANS crowley.
anthony JINN crowley (a rough synonym for ‘demon’ in the quran).
anthony JARARACA crowley (a type of poisonous snake).
anthony JAUNT crowley (he jauntered vaguely downwards).
anthony JAEGER crowley (yes he’s watched pacific rim).
anthony JOTH crowley.
anthony JANTHONY crowley.
or, my personal favourite:
anthony JACKASS crowley.

title: Lead Me Not

by AgentStannerShipper

Heaven sends a rutting Gabriel to try to convince Aziraphale to come back to Heaven. Thanks to his biology, Aziraphale is tempted. Crowley isn’t about to let his angel go without a fight.

summary:
Oh we're on what the j stands for again?
Listen, half the fandom individually got Janthony dropped into their brain like chilly...
body:
Oh we’re on what the j stands for again?

Listen, half the fandom individually got Janthony dropped into their brain like chilly knowledge so until the miniseries comes out to slap us in the face for the dumbassery of our shared braincell, I’m taking it as canon.

reblog.comment:
Oh we’re on what the j stands for again?

Listen, half the fandom individually got Janthony dropped into their brain like chilly knowledge so until the miniseries comes out to slap us in the face for the dumbassery of our shared braincell, I’m taking it as canon.

trail.content_raw:
Oh we’re on what the j stands for again?

Listen, half the fandom individually got Janthony dropped into their brain like chilly knowledge so until the miniseries comes out to slap us in the face for the dumbassery of our shared braincell, I’m taking it as canon.
trail.content:
Oh we’re on what the j stands for again?

Listen, half the fandom individually got Janthony dropped into their brain like chilly knowledge so until the miniseries comes out to slap us in the face for the dumbassery of our shared braincell, I’m taking it as canon.

I'm a Canadian animator for children's television series. In my spare time, I'm an artist, writer, and indie game developer.
I post my art and WIP artwork of games and visual novels I'm working on. I also do commissions on deviantART, and write the occasional academic article.

summary: [image: a small green drawing of Anthony Crowley relaxing and saying “workers deserve 100% of the fruits of their labor” above...
body:
[image: a small green drawing of Anthony Crowley relaxing and saying “workers deserve 100% of the fruits of their labor” above some class notes about Eugene V. Debs.]

We’re reading documents by American socialists in class right now so I drew a comrade Crowley on my notes.
